awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Toward Usable and Ubiquitous Trust Initialization and Secure Networking in Wireless Ad Hoc Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
With billions of smart wireless devices being ubiquitously deployed, safeguarding their networking from cyber attacks has become a challenge. Not only can the devices deployed in a network can be heterogeneous in terms of available computing resources and interfaces, but ordinary users typically have limited technical expertise to perform complicated security configurations. What's more, trust among the devices is often lacking because of the different vendors or distribution channels they have traversed. This project addresses these challenges and proposes a suite of lightweight protocols for initial trust establishment and secure networking of wireless devices. Intrinsic properties of wireless channels, which are available to most wireless devices, are utilized to minimize the dependence on user engagement, prior secrets or any hardware not commonly seen in most smart devices. 

Three research thrusts are proposed to achieve the project's objectives, which take into consideration devices with limited cryptographic capabilities and those with no cryptography at all. The first task aims at minimizing user involvement in the trust initialization process without assuming any extra resources, which is achieved with an obfuscated in-band message authentication protocol. The second task puts forward a mobility-aided authenticated secret key extraction technique without any explicit user involvement. The third task explores key-free wireless security utilizing friendly jamming; a geometry-based computational model is proposed for optimizing the network deployment. The results of this project will lay the foundation for designing extremely lightweight and highly usable secure trust initialization and networking protocols that are compatible with most commercial off-the-shelf smart wireless devices.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we investigated the problem of in-band key establishment over insecure wireless channel for devices without any prior shared secret. An obfuscated authenticated wireless comparison (OAWC) mechanism was designed and validated via a testbed. The proposed design was shown effective in case of both single attackers and multiple cooperative signal cancellation attackers. Different from existing techniques, our design does not require additional hardware or extra assistance devices.

 

In the second research task, we developed a secure and efficient context-based initial trust establishment protocol based on device mobility. The design is based on the observation that in some context (e.g., wearable body networks) user mobility will cause high dynamics to some channels (e.g., those between on-body devices and off-body devices) while some channels are relatively stable (e.g., those between on-body devices in close proximity). Our solution is to utilize dynamic channels for secret key extraction considering the high entropy and latter for context authentication (e.g., whether or not devices are installed on the same platform or body). The authenticated secret key generation protocol was implemented and validated via a body network testbed with a set of TelosB sensors. The research was also extended to support efficient opportunistic communications in body area networks under cross-technique interferences. 

 

Our third research task was to a secure keyless wireless networking protocol. Specifically, we developed a secure wireless federated learning scheme based on the over-the-air computation (AirComp) technology. As compared to existing work, our scheme provides a stronger security protection against attackers with directional antenna. We achieved this by introducing artificial noises to transmitted RF signals at each device. To minimize degradation of learning performance, we made the artificial noises pariwise cancellable between transmitting devices when the signals are received at the local aggregator, be it a base station or an edge server. Analytical results and simulation show that our design is effective and secure. The convergence rate of the federate learning algorithm was shown bounded to a threshold. 

 

In addition to the above outcomes, the research of this project has also resulted in impacts on related problems such as wireless localization, wireless computation in multi-access channels and machine learning especially federated learning.
